column1857:
15/Nov/23 1:41 PM;5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358;Hi [~accountid:62e3f1525f7842fb1294980c] ,

regarding the double to int conversion, I personally think that rounding makes more sense but can you please check what the current production code does?

I don’t think this decision will have much impact, because the prices returned via xDist should already be rounded. 

On some of the other discussion points…

From a design point of view we need to ensure that b/w SOLR 

* accepts queries based on field names and formats that SOLR queries currently use
* internally it does any necessary conversion into CNG field names / types before querying the index
* does a similar translation of the returned data into SOLR field names and types before sending the query response

A lot of the problems reported originally appeared to be due to the above type of logic not being fully in place.

B/W SOLR doesn't need to support queries with field formats that it doesn't accept today

The issues with totalRoundedPrice are probably due to when in the sequence of events this field is being generated. From b/w SOLR point of view it's a totally separate field. It should be able to be returned via fl or in the default field list separately from the field it is generated from.
It should also be able to be queried in the same way as other fields.

Thanks,

Jon

In this Jira for below example   departure Date range given from 2023-07-17T00:00:00Z TO 2024-07-01T23:59:[*99*|https://g2qqlg0esi.execute-api.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/dev/solr/carPackages/select/?q=*:*&fq=(departureDate:%5B2023-07-17T00:00:00Z+TO+2024-07-01T23:59:99Z%5D)]*Z ,*  in which the seconds part is invalid. 

[https://g2qqlg0esi.execute-api.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/dev/solr/carPackages/select/?q=*:*&fq=(departureDate:%5B2023-07-17T00:00:00Z+TO+2024-07-01T23:59:99Z%5D)|https://g2qqlg0esi.execute-api.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/dev/solr/carPackages/select/?q=*:*&fq=(departureDate:%5B2023-07-17T00:00:00Z+TO+2024-07-01T23:59:99Z%5D)]

[https://ba.com/solr/carPackages/select/?q=*:*&fq=(departureDate:%5B2023-07-17T00:00:00Z+TO+2024-07-01T23:59:99Z%5D)|https://g2qqlg0esi.execute-api.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/dev/solr/carPackages/select/?q=*:*&fq=(departureDate:%5B2023-07-17T00:00:00Z+TO+2024-07-01T23:59:99Z%5D)]

The above request is working live SOLR.  In CNG application due to invalid date we are getting error.  Please let us know your inputs about how we need to handle such invalid dates in CNG?

Thanks & Regards,

Merin Joseph
column1857:
15/Nov/23 4:26 PM;5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358;Hi [~accountid:62e3f1525f7842fb1294980c] [~accountid:5d14ba9bbda1410bc8e04883] 

Are both of the [ba.com|http://ba.com] SOLR url examples genuine requests from live?

Live SOLR currently copes with queries with different numbers of decimals places in the seconds field and returns results correctly. 

Assuming live is receiving and handling these successfully today, then b/w SOLR needs to be robust enough to do this as well. Please can you check the live code to see how this is done today.

As far as I'm aware we don't have anything in SOLR with decimals places in the seconds field. In fact I wouldn't expect anything to have second values  in the timestamp either, given that we only display hours and minutes for flight and car pick up times.(expect 00 secs)

I therefore don’t think that any values in the seconds part of the timestamps should be important in determining what data is returned, but we do need to make sure that they don’t prevent a search from failing when it’s successful today. Please can you validate this as part of the as-is SOLR analysis.

The 2nd example url isn’t a test one (possibly with a type) sent through by one of us is it? Might be worth checking the ip address in log files to see if this scenario can be discounted.

Thanks,

Jon

column1: Commercial Analysis - Job status and Error Logging
column45:
*Epic requirement:*

* [ER.21|https://baplc.sharepoint.com/:x:/r/sites/BAHProjects/(3844b)%20%20Cache%20%20Next%20Gen2/Requirements%20Analysis%20and%20Design/20180215%203844b%20Cache%20Next%20Gen%20PRL%20%20v1.2%20(SF).xlsx?d=w0d3c2f04eae34601817bb33295c20dc9&csf=1&e=VCErDS]

*Requirement:*

{color:#ff5630}*As a*{color}{color:#0747a6} {color}member of the Commercial Analysis team 

{color:#ff5630}*I want*{color} clear summary information to be visible for each run of all scheduled queries

{color:#ff5630}*So that*{color} I can see if the run has been successful and identify if any errors have occurred



*Acceptance criteria:*

*AC1 - Job status & error logging*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} a scheduled query has been executed in a predefined time slot

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} the job has completed

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} data is written to a summary table and this should include:

* the job id that ran
* the time slot is was scheduled to run 
* the scheduled sequence of the job
* whether the query runs in isolation or as part of a group with other queries
* Actual Start date & time
* Actual End date & time
* How many rows were returned by the query
* The target table
* Whether the target table was cleared before data was inserted
* Overall Job status
* Any relevant error messages from logs

Note - data should not be written into the table for empty pre-defined slots or slots where the query is currently disabled (ie where no scheduled queries have run)



*AC2 - Error logging across all stages & components*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} a scheduled query has been executed

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} an error occurs 

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} error messages are captured and written into relevant logs - regardless of the stage or component that failed

column1: Commercial Analysis - Query language and capabilities
column45:
*Background*

* The number of rows being returned for current APC queries vary between 8,000 to 300,000 records
* CNG will support 3 times volume of cached results initially and this may continue to grow in the future - so the system will need to be able to support result sets with millions of rows

*Epic requirement:*

* [ER.21|https://baplc.sharepoint.com/:x:/r/sites/BAHProjects/(3844b)%20%20Cache%20%20Next%20Gen2/Requirements%20Analysis%20and%20Design/20180215%203844b%20Cache%20Next%20Gen%20PRL%20%20v1.2%20(SF).xlsx?d=w0d3c2f04eae34601817bb33295c20dc9&csf=1&e=VCErDS]



*Requirement:*

{color:#ff5630}*As a*{color}{color:#0747a6} {color}member of the Commercial Analysis team

{color:#ff5630}*I want*{color} to be able to use Elasticsearch SQL (and all it’s associated capabilities) as the query language

{color:#ff5630}*So that*{color} I can easily generate SQL style statements to retrieve data from any of the Elasticsearch indexes ( without having to use Elasticsearch DSL query language)



*Acceptance criteria:*

*AC1 - Data retrieval & correctness*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} a valid scheduled or ad-hoc Elasticsearch SQL query has been executed against any CNG index

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} the query has completed

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} :

* all the requested fields are returned in the query results (and no others)
* all SQL operators in the query have been correctly executed



*AC2 - Data volume*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} a valid scheduled or ad-hoc Elasticsearch SQL query has been executed

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} the query returns large datasets (eg several million rows)

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} all the requested rows are returned in one go (ie the system will automatically manage any paging through large data sets)



*AC3 - Concurrent queries*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} that one or more ELS SQL queries are already running 

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} another ELS SQL queries is executed 

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} : all queries should end successfully (albeit they may run slower)



*Additional Information:*

* the TCS technical solution should not implement logic mapping the Elasticsearch SQL to DSL query language. This is not required because Elasticsearch does this automatically before executing the query.
* it is not required to support retrieving data from more than 1 index with a single query. If data is reqd from separate indices, then this will be done using separate queries
* General guidance to the CA team will be that for scheduled queries, they should try and avoid queries having overlapping run times - making tracking easier. This cannot be guaranteed however and Ad-hoc queries could be triggered at any point during the working day.

column1856:
23/Oct/23 12:59 PM;5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358;Hi [~accountid:64259c719796ea0a8719cd03] ,

I’ve managed to get some timings from the CA team on last weeks competitor analysis queries along with some supporting info:

|process_id|start_time|finish_time|hh:mm|count of records|
|BEACH LA|19/10/2023 08:30|19/10/2023 08:34|00:04|435975|
|CITY|18/10/2023 08:30|18/10/2023 08:35|00:05|438530|
|BEACH|17/10/2023 08:30|17/10/2023 08:33|00:03|430011|
|NYC|15/10/2023 08:49|15/10/2023 09:04|00:14|8386|
|ROW|15/10/2023 08:30|15/10/2023 08:49|00:19|32817|

The SQL scripts are virtually identical, with the sole variation being how the city codes used. The key distinction lies in the mid-week queries, where all cities are incorporated within a single query, sharing the same duration. Consequently, these require fewer queries to execute. On Sunday (15th), ROW, and USA, multiple queries are run at the city level, each employing different where clauses and are not grouped together. Consequently, running these queries may consume more time.

It's also worth noting that the infrastructure team takes a comprehensive backup during the weekends, which might also impact the query execution times.

Jon

column1: Commercial Analysis - Price comparison report
column45:
*Background*

* One of the current critical CA team queries is the Pricing Report
* Currently this is run on an ad-hoc basis but in the future it may be changed to be a scheduled query
* The query will need to be re-written before go live to use Elasticsearch SQL and to reference fields in CNG indices

*Epic requirement:*

* [ER.21|https://baplc.sharepoint.com/:x:/r/sites/BAHProjects/(3844b)%20%20Cache%20%20Next%20Gen2/Requirements%20Analysis%20and%20Design/20180215%203844b%20Cache%20Next%20Gen%20PRL%20%20v1.2%20(SF).xlsx?d=w0d3c2f04eae34601817bb33295c20dc9&csf=1&e=VCErDS]

*Requirement:*

{color:#ff5630}*As a*{color}{color:#0747a6} {color}member of the Commercial Analysis team

{color:#ff5630}*I want*{color} to be able to run an updated version of the Pricing Report

{color:#ff5630}*So that*{color} all required pricing related information can be retrieved and analysed



*Acceptance criteria:*

*AC1 - Running the Pricing Report as an ad-hoc query*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} an updated version of the Pricing Report has been written

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} the query is run as an ad-hoc query

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} all expected data (consistent with the query details and cached data) is returned to the user  



*AC2 - Running Pricing Report as a scheduled query*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} an updated version of the Pricing Report has been written

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} the query is setup in the configuration table for scheduled queries

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} :

* It is triggered at the expected date & time
* all expected data (consistent with the query details and cached data) is returned to the user

*Additional Information*

* Scott Nimmo needs to get the latest version of the pricing report(s) before it can be converted into ELS SQL
* BAH will write the updated pricing report

column1: Commercial Analysis - Running Ad-hoc queries
column45:
*Background Information*

Currently ad-hoc queries can be run 

* From the SQL server by the Commercial analysis team
* From a users PC (Commercial Analysis team or Yield team) using an appropriate DB tool to connect to the APC cache DB
* results can be extracted to SQL server / local PC / LAN / Cloud depending on what the user requires at that time

*Epic requirement:*

* [ER.21|https://baplc.sharepoint.com/:x:/r/sites/BAHProjects/(3844b)%20%20Cache%20%20Next%20Gen2/Requirements%20Analysis%20and%20Design/20180215%203844b%20Cache%20Next%20Gen%20PRL%20%20v1.2%20(SF).xlsx?d=w0d3c2f04eae34601817bb33295c20dc9&csf=1&e=VCErDS]

*Requirement:*

{color:#ff5630}*As a*{color}{color:#0747a6} {color}member of the Commercial Analysis or Yield team

{color:#ff5630}*I want*{color} a mechanism to submit Elasticsearch SQL queries at any point during the day / week 

{color:#ff5630}*So that*{color} they can be triggered immediately and the data can be easily extracted and shared by the user

*Acceptance criteria:*

*AC1 - Immediate run*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} an-hoc query has been written by a user

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} the query is submitted

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} it is executed immediately (ie the system does not wait until the next slot for scheduled queries to run the query)

*AC2 - Data extraction*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} an-hoc query has been submitted by the user

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} the query completes

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} :

* the data is returned to the user as one complete data set regardless of size
* This data set is in a format (eg csv, excel) that can be easily moved to other locations as the users desires.
* The user does not have to manually cut & paste the data in order to retrieve it

*AC3 - Failed ad-hoc queries*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} an-hoc query has been submitted by the user 

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} the query encounters a problem causing it to fail

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} an error message is clearly displayed to the user 



*Additional information*

* If it turns out that it’s not possible to trigger the query instantly, then it should be queued instantly and triggered as soon as possible after this
* I believe Kibana has a limitation of 10M when extracting data using the *Discover → Share* option, but our data sets could be larger than this
* *Kibana dev tools* also has a limitation on the number of rows it can retrieve in one page - I think this is 10,000. Data sets could be larger than this

column1: Commercial Analysis - Competitor Analysis Process
column45:
*Background information:*

* Commercial Analysis team run Competitor Analysis queries at specified times and days of week
* They run on an Microsoft SQL Server ‘bahsql1’, which is connected directly to the APC Oracle DB as a linked remote server. 
* The Commercial Analysis team maintain both the SQL queries and also the scheduling on the bahsql1 server. 
* The output of the Competitor analysis queries is returned to the server and stored in the DB.
* Competitor prices such as those from Expedia and Virgin are obtained by BAH querying third party system owned by a company called Infare. 
* The data from Infare is then compared against the data extracted from the cache
* The query will need to be re-written before go live to use Elasticsearch SQL and to reference fields in CNG indices

*Requirement:*

{color:#ff5630}*As a*{color}{color:#0747a6} {color}member of the Commercial Analysis team

{color:#ff5630}*I want*{color} to be able to schedule all Competitor Analysis queries that will run throughout the week

{color:#ff5630}*So that*{color} they run automatically and output the data required for the downstream Competitor Analysis processes



*AC1 - Running Competitor Analysis queries as a scheduled queries*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} the Commercial Analysis team have setup numerous entries in the config table for Competitor Analysis queries

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} the schedule runs for an entire week

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} :

* All the enabled Competitor Analysis queries are triggered at the expected date & time
* All expected data (consistent with the query details and cached data) for each query is returned to the specified target table on the SQL server



*Additional Information:*

* BAH will write the updated Competitor analysis queries
* The downstream part of this process (after the target tables have been populated) is out of scope for CNG and we don’t need to consider that

column1: Commercial Analysis - schedule and configuration for regular queries
column45:
*Background Information (current process)*

* Commercial Analysis team run scheduled queries run at specified times and days of week
* Commercial Analysis can setup and maintain the queries that run, including setting up new queries and decommissioning ones that are no longer required
* Commercial Analysis team can setup and maintain schedule of what runs and when - this is controlled on the SQL server
* Currently there is a lot of duplication in these queries
** the same basic query exists multiple times for different destinations (ie SELECT part the same, but with different WHERE clauses)
** this is all hardcoded and there’s no parameterisation, making maintenance time consuming - CA team are looking to improve this if possible
* Query results are automatically returned to SQL server and can be saved in the DB

*Epic requirement:*

* [ER.21|https://baplc.sharepoint.com/:x:/r/sites/BAHProjects/(3844b)%20%20Cache%20%20Next%20Gen2/Requirements%20Analysis%20and%20Design/20180215%203844b%20Cache%20Next%20Gen%20PRL%20%20v1.2%20(SF).xlsx?d=w0d3c2f04eae34601817bb33295c20dc9&csf=1&e=VCErDS]

*Requirement:*

{color:#ff5630}*As a*{color}{color:#0747a6} {color}member of the Commercial Analysis team

{color:#ff5630}*I want*{color} a configuration table to setup and submit queries at specific times during the week

{color:#ff5630}*So that*{color} they run automatically and do not require manual submission



*Acceptance criteria:*

*AC1 - Setup of a scheduled query*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} a configuration table exists to control scheduled queries

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} a member of the CA team adds or amends data within the table

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} : The following data can be defined and maintained for each query:

* the time of day it runs (controllable to within 15 min slots)
* the days of the week the query should run on (none, one, multiple, all) 
* the target table on the SQL server where the returned data should be inserted
* whether the target table is cleared down or not before the query runs
* whether the query runs in isolation or as part of a group with other queries 
* the select and where clauses for the query 
* whether the entry is currently enabled or disabled
* a comment field to clarify what entry in the table does



*AC2 - Running of an individual scheduled query*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} an entry has been setup in the configuration table for a specific query

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} the day and time for the next run of the query is reached 

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} : 

IF the record is set to enabled:

* the data in the target table is retained or deleted as per the config table setting
* the full query is created by combining the select and where clauses from the config table and executed
* the complete results set is written into the target table on the SQL server

IF the record is set to disabled then no action is taken



*AC3 - Running of grouped scheduled queries*

{color:#ff5630}*Given*{color} a number of queries have been setup to run together in a group

{color:#ff5630}*When*{color} the day and time for the next run of the group is reached 

{color:#ff5630}*Then*{color} : 

* The system uses the config table to identify which order the queries should run in
* the queries in the group are executed in the defined sequence
* any disabled queries are ignored and not run
* When one query completes, the next query in the group is executed immediately (there is no delay until the next scheduled slot)
* Data in the target table can continue to build up over multiple queries (assuming config settings define this)
* when the last query in the group completes, the group is considered finished
* if any of the queries in the group fails, then the system should *stop processing subsequent queries in the group*. The rest of the schedule should be unaffected if this occurs and continue to run.



*Additional Information:*

* BAH require a generic solution that will support all current and any future queries BAH may want to submit
* This will include the ability to update the details of existing queries and structure of target tables over time (if reqd)
* As the config table and target tables will reside on SQL server, the CA team will be responsible for setup and maintenance of them
* CA team will also be responsible for ensuring compatibility of the scheduled queries with both CNG index and the target tables (field name, sizes, formats etc)
* CA are also responsible for ensuring that that the run times setup in the config table match the pre-defined run times setup in AWS
* The solution will need performance testing. As part of this it would be good to understand the performance impacts of running a smaller number of queries returning larger amounts of data vs a larger number of scripts returning smaller datasets. This would help the CA team understand how to split up their queries.
* The idea of grouping queries is primarily designed for instances where we want to retrieve a lot of similar pricing information into the same target table for many destinations. (ie where we need to split the queries up for performance reasons. )
** Grouping allows us to keep adding data results into the same target table giving one large result sets across several queries
** Grouping also allows immediate triggering of the next query in the group - reducing ‘dead time’ in the schedule 
* CA team have requested that if any query in a group fails, then other queries in the group should not be executed. 

Questions:

* If there are failures part way through data insertion into target table what will happen? Will all data updates be rolled back?

column1856:
29/Feb/24 11:16 AM;5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358;BAH had an action to clarify what the requirement is in the situation where one query within a group fails.

* The CA team would like to change the approach and just stop executing all queries within the group if one fails. (Which probably makes things simpler)
* I have updated the last point in AC3 to reflect this.
* AC4 also becomes irrelevant with this change, so I have removed it....from a business perspective it doesn't matter whether the cleardown instruction runs or not - the whole group will need re-executing at some point. 

Thanks,

Jon

column1860:
13/Mar/24 4:33 PM;635145e8f7ad721e784c7e20;*From the Security team:*

[4:19 PM] Shafiqul Islam

Hi Everyone, vulnerabilities were identified:

 

While going through the count of vulnerabilities in the subject Non-Production account, I could see high count of vulnerabilities, probably due to unwanted images/untagged older version.

These images might not be of use to your account but contributing to the high count of vulnerabilities.

 

Below is the snapshot of details, I can view from AWS Inspector. (Same details would be visible to you as well, from Inspector Console).

 

*Snapshot of Account:*

 

*Repository findings*

 

Starting point of remediation is to perform the housekeeping of the account/images and in turn reduce the unwanted vulnerabilities.

We can achieve it by implementing the ECR lifecycle policies.

 

[https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/LifecyclePolicies.html|https://eur02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.aws.amazon.com%2FAmazonECR%2Flatest%2Fuserguide%2FLifecyclePolicies.html&data=05%7C02%7Cshafiqul.islam%40iaggbs.com%7Cb16f09d3a92d4bbca19d08dc43423501%7Cc28eb601be1d491889f40d1b73c2ddc5%7C0%7C0%7C638459198856019434%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C0%7C%7C%7C&sdata=wFgXeB6j4lBrlK0Dj8hFk6LGezojiETJNSXmSuSyF0Q%3D&reserved=0] (I have shared a link to the documentation of the Lifecyle policies and example of lifecycle policies for your reference)

 

*_Note: Verify the affected images of the test run and then apply the Lifecycle rule._*

 

Secondly, we can perform the remediation of the findings of the image *Resource ID* _EQUALS_ arn:aws:ecr:eu-west-1:025700222871:repository/bah-cng-solr-ecp-dev/sha256:87d82edb5e6b4c95012aaca17355be5b085fd9795ab448e0d4f363e46b8088a4

There are similar findings on the three tagged images in the repository.

Scanning for vulnerabilities in dependencies and libraries is done on daily basis, recommended tool is 

*Snyk*:  scanning must show 0 critical vulnerability in the system.

Currently exploring licensing and other details to integrate during pipeline build process (mandatory).

# Jira’s in UAT will be picked up for Regression Testing again and once confirmed to be working will be moved to UAT.
# Jira’s marked as Work Complete / Done if the Changes are already in Live then will be Marked as Work Complete with appropriate comments and no actions to be taken.
# Jira’s marked as Work Complete / Done if the Changes are in UAT stages then it will be moved to Regression testing again and retested. Then moved to UAT.

This activity is on lower priority for now, as we are focusing first on the Ways of Working and setting up the standards for SOLR API. Once we commence the plan for TCS delivery this will be picked up.

15/Sep/23 10:55 PM;62e3f2fd3aaeedcae756b1f3;Hi Jon,

I believe you are already working on this requirement based on my discussion with Shaf today. However, for clarity I am defining what is needed as part of this requirement.

# User Stories needed for Day 1
# Prioritization of must have’s

column1858:
20/Sep/23 3:52 PM;5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358;Hi [~accountid:62e3f2fd3aaeedcae756b1f3] . 

* By default, all requirements can currently be considered as Day1 deliverables, unless the ‘Not-Day1’ label has been assigned. Only a few Jiras have this label
* By Day 1 here, I’m referring to when the system is switched on, rather than the dates of any (potentially incremental) code drops into the live environment
* There hasn’t been any prioritisation of the requirements in MSCW terms…anything that hasn’t been assigned ‘Not-Day1 is expected to be available immediately the system is switched on. Unless we have any specific conversations about descoping certain items, then this will remain the case.



I’m thinking we might want an additional label to cover anything that we decide that we would definitely never implement rather than leaving at as  ‘Not-Day1’ label , where it still would look like a possibility for the future. Shall I add this in?

We can then view the different slices of requirements by using the existing requirements labels and ( removing ‘Not-Day1' and never implement Jiras if relevant for the query.)

Will this give you all the filtering that you require?

Jon
column1859:
21/Sep/23 10:09 AM;62e3f2fd3aaeedcae756b1f3;Hi Jon,

Based on our previous discussions, we have finalized the Label for SOLR API as SOLR_requirement and with that we are clear it covers the scope for the delivery for Day 1. 

We have created a dashboard for SOLR requirement [[ALL CNG SOLR REQUIREMENTS] Issue navigator - Jira (atlassian.net)|https://iagtech.atlassian.net/issues/?filter=21040]. It lists down all 29 requirements which we need to consider. So from SOLR API perspective we are clear and the items are under TCS review. 

As you are working on other items to put the right LABELS for each of the User Stories you can update the same table below once you have done for next set of Stories. 

|Area|Label|Meaning|Status|
|Requirements|SOLR_requirement|Requirement for SOLR|LABELLING COMPLETED in TCS Review|
| |SIP_requirement|Requirement for SIP| |
| |Full_Requirement|Requirement for Full API| |
| |tech_requirement|Technical requirement normally originating from technical standards, vulnerabilities or components being out of date| |
| |Housekeeping_requirement|Requirement for Housekeeping| |
| |BB_requirement|Requirement for Burst and / or Batch controller| |
| |CMT_requirement|Requirement for CMT| |
| |Misc_requirement|Other requirements| |

Thanks and Regards

column1857:
20/Sep/23 4:17 PM;5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358;Sorry [~accountid:62e3f2fd3aaeedcae756b1f3] is the Jira asking for:

* a  standard definition of when BAH would consider a user requirements story to be complete and can be set to status DONE?
* Or to review if the existing user stories in DONE status is correct?
* Or anything else?

For the first one, up to this point we have been setting user reqs stories to DONE once UAT has been completed successfully for all parts of the Jira ie all acceptance criteria have completed UAT. We haven’t been keeping the story open for any subsequent code moves to live etc. 

For some of the more technical reqs ( tech_requirements) there may not be any meaningful UAT we can do, so we’d mark that as Done when SIT was complete.

 [~accountid:635145e8f7ad721e784c7e20]  - are you happy to keep with the same approach going forward? 

For the 2nd point, it will need a general review by TCS as well to confirm if the current status of Jiras is correct. For example, if we had a story that was set to  Done or UAT and then the code needed to be refactored (ie after a code review ) then the status might need to be updated. I guessing this probably isn’t what you meant in this Jira but would be a task for later on.

Thanks,

Jon

column1: CR - All APIs - Logging
column45:
one more thing we might address in the SIP/SOLR/FULL LLDs in the logging section, is to make sure we are logging enough into cloudwatch for analytics and operational monitoring.

For example that we have the kind of info as the current CAPTWO logs - or SOLR apache logs which we have been analysing recently to figure out existing solr features / clients / etc.

I suppose API gateway can log this information. [https://docs.aws.amazon.com/apigateway/latest/developerguide/set-up-logging.html|https://eur02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.aws.amazon.com%2Fapigateway%2Flatest%2Fdeveloperguide%2Fset-up-logging.html&data=05%7C01%7Csana.fathima%40ba.com%7C777b9250fb7a446c677d08dba4789bc5%7Cddd66cceffe14029967c5e15ef73127f%7C0%7C0%7C638284611813978463%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=P6%2B5JthOqI1%2Bme2tLBp%2BjjjrzVlHEafUyEsWaiOggZY%3D&reserved=0]     I suggest at least combined format (the referrer and user-agent was helpful analysing solr apache logs) plus duration which I believe is $context.responseLatency  [https://docs.aws.amazon.com/apigateway/latest/developerguide/api-gateway-mapping-template-reference.html#context-variable-reference-access-logging-only|https://eur02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.aws.amazon.com%2Fapigateway%2Flatest%2Fdeveloperguide%2Fapi-gateway-mapping-template-reference.html%23context-variable-reference-access-logging-only&data=05%7C01%7Csana.fathima%40ba.com%7C777b9250fb7a446c677d08dba4789bc5%7Cddd66cceffe14029967c5e15ef73127f%7C0%7C0%7C638284611813978463%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=NoC0nXPU6q%2F1H0EH9pTS52o2kEuKU1wvsUiw%2By5JylQ%3D&reserved=0]

For the full api also the user, which might be $context.authorizer.principalId  . We should not log passwords or tokens etc.

if you prefer json format fine.

For lambda authorizers there is other info that we need to log.  This randomly found blog on the Internet seemed quite helpful [https://www.alexdebrie.com/posts/api-gateway-access-logs/|https://eur02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.alexdebrie.com%2Fposts%2Fapi-gateway-access-logs%2F&data=05%7C01%7Csana.fathima%40ba.com%7C777b9250fb7a446c677d08dba4789bc5%7Cddd66cceffe14029967c5e15ef73127f%7C0%7C0%7C638284611814134693%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=iago%2BRJit5ZZt459%2FxemtxUuOjsD2D%2FnT%2BTCnG5avw4%3D&reserved=0]

I suppose for logging in API gateway we have to ask Version 1 to set it up, but we have to tell them exactly what we want.

Later when we get to the support handover we will have to define dashboards and alerts, but since we do not know what the support team will be we can’t do that yet.  At this stage we need to make sure that we put enough info into cloudwatch.

column1: SOLR API - Internal Consumers Env Set Up - Content Proxy Or Global Cloud Connect
column45:
+Description+

02-Aug

 during weekly connects with CTTI , A cyber point of view was considered whether it is OK to connect from within the BA network to an AWS service over the Internet,

Or does it have to be via the Global Cloud Connect (or a VPN)

+Decision+

18-Aug

BA Cyber advised that they will not allow connecting from on-prem servers through content-proxy via Internet to AWS services bypassing Akamai. We’ll have to connect On-prem servers through Global Cloud Connect.



+Actions:+

Following review comments were generated based on the decision above:

|SOLR API LLD|2.5 CNG 79: Internal consumers / Internal consumer cut over
I got an answer back from BA Cyber - we cannot route the requests from internal BA servers via content-proxy over over the Internet to our public API bypassing Akamai.  Instead we have to go via Global Cloud Connect|
|SOLR API LLD|2.5 CNG 79: Internal consumers / Internal consumer cut over
Consumer endpoint: There is no endpoint change in the consumer end
This is true in short-term but we it would be better to schedule endpoint changes in the various internal clients (captwo, livesite, teamsite, cap webchannel ...) to change their endpoint rather than going via apache solr proxy at [www.britishairways.com/solr/mmbHotels|http://www.britishairways.com/solr/mmbHotels] etc go directly (via Global Cloud Connect) to [api.internal.bahcache.com/solr/mmbHotels|http://api.internal.bahcache.com/solr/mmbHotels].  Of course for that, we will need additional firewall rules for each client server that needs to connect, and we will have to get endpoint change implemented in each client.  Alternatively perhaps we wait till those client systems migrate to AWS and update their endpoints with that, however it might get a bit confusing with DC Exit, because by default they will migrate as-is so we would end up with captwo migrated to AWS calling on-prem solr-apache which proxies it back to AWS.  I suppose we could get CR's in place with the various DC Exit projects for captwo, cap, livesite, teamsite.  Anyway, sometime after we go live we would decomm all our SOLR indexes and preferably disconnect all the internal clients from our old SOLR endpoints.|
|SOLR API LLD|"Consumers are not required to change anything from their end. They will query and get same response as like as today. The only change is an endpoint url redirection of the service."
Better to not say "endpoint url redirection" because this suggests the endpoint might return a HTTP 302 redirect response, which is not the case (and which clients might not handle). Instead something like "We will use path-based routing in akamai to route requests for the 4 CNG indexes to SOLR API cloud origin instead of the current [ba.com|http://ba.com] origin."|
|SOLR API LLD|2.6 "Overall internal and external consumer’s flow" diagram
As above, I got an answer back from BA Cyber - we cannot route the requests from internal BA servers via content-proxy over over the Internet to our public API bypassing Akamai.  Instead we have to go via Global Cloud Connect.  So replace by the option 2 diagram.|

column1857:
14/Aug/23 12:05 PM;5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358;Hi [~accountid:5ad8cbca926ac92a7c0e11bb]  - I’ve gone through the Jiras now, it was quite hard in some instances to make a decision but I’ve done the best I can.

I’ve updated the ‘*All CNG Requirements - new’* filter to be based on labels now rather than just the Story Jira type. A few things to note:

* In some instances we have several similar Jiras. I’ve normally tried to just label one of them eg the original requirement
* However, in some instances there are other later Jiras in the same area where additional considerations have been discussed or agreed. Where I’ve seen these, I’ve labelled them as a requirement as well, because it has additional considerations
* There are quite a lot Jiras that I’ve labelled as tech_requirements. I’ve tried to do this where the Jira is adding in additional considerations that aren’t present in the designs docs - eg where Nigel has spotted an issue or additional info has been rec’d from BA security. In some circumstances I had to make a bit of a guess…if you think any of these don’t make sense, then let me know.
* The filter shows all requirements including those for non-TCS deliveries and ones where the work has already been completed.
* There are also some in the list which have marked as not being required for Day 1…or could in the future be marked as this.

Can you please have a look through the list and let me know if this as you were expecting? 

Thanks,

Jon

G. Is the requirement high level and needs to be broken down

H. Comments



This will help us understand if all the requirements have been addressed or anything outstanding that is part of requirements but not under our radar.

Thanks in advance.

I understand this is a tedious task but we need this to ensure that we are on the right track and accounted everything in our planning

Sana

column1856:
09/Aug/23 11:50 AM;63ae73fbf3e7004f77fd79ad;Comments from Nigel:

The NAT-ted IP for BAH sql-server database ([BAHSQL1.bah.ba.com|http://BAHSQL1.bah.ba.com] with private IP 10.225.20.45) that you have to connect to from AWS is 23.239.128.34

See if you can connect to 23.239.128.34 port 1433 from our AWS dev or prelive account transit VPC.

previously Version 1 (Neha) set up an EC2 instance in one of the transit VPC.

So, just to check connectivity if you ssh onto that EC2 instance you should be able to curl 23.239.128.34:1433 and get something back from curl that tells you it got through.  Like a 403 or something like that.
column1857:
15/Aug/23 9:38 PM;635145e8f7ad721e784c7e20;[16:30] Nigel Hassett

Shaf, we might be a bit premature with this request for 23.239.128.34 .  BT have changed the NAT IP now (they made me raise another RFS for this yesterday) and are still working on it.  We should wait for BT to finish.
column1858:
22/Aug/23 7:09 PM;616007b564ff01007180a9c5;Correction to IP mentioned below.

on-prem NAT-ted IP should be 23.239.128.41.  

Port is still 1433

Per [https://iagtech.atlassian.net/browse/CNG-865|https://iagtech.atlassian.net/browse/CNG-865|smart-link] BA firewall is complete and v1 added the route (point a) and successfully tested connectivy from _transit VPC_ .
column1859:
22/Aug/23 7:53 PM;616007b564ff01007180a9c5;Point (b) is pending.  btw there are 2 NAT gateways in the dev account bah-dev-Nat-gw and bah-reg-Nat-gw but these seem to be for something else (connecting to the Internet I suppose?) since they have public IPs eg bah-reg-Nat-gw has 34.248.126.50.

Instead we need a NAT gateway in the _transit_ VPC, for connecting to on-prem resources, with an IP in the shared address space range allocated to the transit VPC 100.64.43.128/26. A lambda function in the private VPC with private 172.* IP can connect to the on-prem database via this NAT gateway in the transit VPC, which will present its 100.64.* IP to the on-prem server. 

See[https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/nat-gateway-scenarios.html|https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/nat-gateway-scenarios.html|smart-link] “Access your network using allow-listed IP addresses”  [by the way, if BA holidays later move their on-prem database moves to AWS, it will still go via the NAT gateway in the transit VPC but we will change to the 3rd usecase “Enable communication between overlapping networks”]

For info, IAG policy does not allow connecting private IPs between on-prem and AWS.

In this case, the on-prem database has a private IP 10.225.20.45 - it is NAT-ted at the BA side to public IP 23.239.128.41.  The AWS lambda functions in the private VPC have private IPs 172.* - they have to be NAT-ted at the AWS side to a shared address space IP in the 100.64.43.128/26 CIDR.
column1860: 26/Oct/23 5:23 PM;616007b564ff01007180a9c5;for info, BAH are moving their SQL Server from their current datacentre at Astral Towers initially this weekend (26 - 30 oct) to the BA datacenter at Boho and then within 28 days to a new (ECP) AWS account.  So the IP might change and there will be new firewall rules. Also, this will then be AWS to AWS connection which should be easy enough from our new ECP account but not sure the process from our existing legacy account. There is also the fact that BA Cyber will require it to be secure in AWS, but BAH might use internal IAG-issued certificate.

column1: CNG - All API- XDistributor - ST - Different behaviour between APC and CNG when grouping on certain date fields
column45:
Whilst I was doing some comparisons between the existing SOLr responses and the new b/w SOLr API, I noticed some differences with a query that was grouping results based on departure date.

[https://www.britishairways.com/solr/hotelPackages/hfHandler/?q=*:*&sort=depDate%20asc&fq=overallCabin:M&fq=duration:3&fq=depAirportCode_1_O:(LHR%20OR%20LGW%20OR%20LCY%20OR%20LTN%20OT%20STN)&fq=destAirportCode:PAR&fq=marketCode:GB&fq=flightDepDate_1_O:[NOW%20TO%202023-08-20T00:00:00Z]&group=true&|https://www.britishairways.com/solr/hotelPackages/hfHandler/?q=*:*&sort=depDate%20asc&fq=overallCabin:M&fq=duration:3&fq=depAirportCode_1_O:(LHR%20OR%20LGW%20OR%20LCY%20OR%20LTN%20OT%20STN)&fq=destAirportCode:PAR&fq=marketCode:GB&fq=flightDepDate_1_O:[NOW%20TO%202023-08-20T00:00:00Z]&group=true&group.field=depDateString&group.ngroups=true&group.sort=pricePP%20asc&fl=hotelID,depDate,pricePP,deepLink,checkInDate,checkOutDate,duration,depAirportCode_1_O,depAirportName_1_O,roomType,boardBasis,cabinCode_1_O,overallCabin&rows=40&wt=json&indent=on][*group.field=depDateString*|https://www.britishairways.com/solr/hotelPackages/hfHandler/?q=*:*&sort=depDate%20asc&fq=overallCabin:M&fq=duration:3&fq=depAirportCode_1_O:(LHR%20OR%20LGW%20OR%20LCY%20OR%20LTN%20OT%20STN)&fq=destAirportCode:PAR&fq=marketCode:GB&fq=flightDepDate_1_O:[NOW%20TO%202023-08-20T00:00:00Z]&group=true&group.field=depDateString&group.ngroups=true&group.sort=pricePP%20asc&fl=hotelID,depDate,pricePP,deepLink,checkInDate,checkOutDate,duration,depAirportCode_1_O,depAirportName_1_O,roomType,boardBasis,cabinCode_1_O,overallCabin&rows=40&wt=json&indent=on][&group.ngroups=true&group.sort=pricePP%20asc&fl=hotelID,depDate,pricePP,deepLink,checkInDate,checkOutDate,duration,depAirportCode_1_O,depAirportName_1_O,roomType,boardBasis,cabinCode_1_O,overallCabin&rows=40&wt=json&indent=on|https://www.britishairways.com/solr/hotelPackages/hfHandler/?q=*:*&sort=depDate%20asc&fq=overallCabin:M&fq=duration:3&fq=depAirportCode_1_O:(LHR%20OR%20LGW%20OR%20LCY%20OR%20LTN%20OT%20STN)&fq=destAirportCode:PAR&fq=marketCode:GB&fq=flightDepDate_1_O:[NOW%20TO%202023-08-20T00:00:00Z]&group=true&group.field=depDateString&group.ngroups=true&group.sort=pricePP%20asc&fl=hotelID,depDate,pricePP,deepLink,checkInDate,checkOutDate,duration,depAirportCode_1_O,depAirportName_1_O,roomType,boardBasis,cabinCode_1_O,overallCabin&rows=40&wt=json&indent=on]

It turned out that this wasn't anything to do with the API as such, but it was being caused by a difference in the indexed data. 

* In todays APC, all the departure date timestamps time portions get set to 12:00 in the SOLr extract (not in the DB). 
* So if HolidayFinder (or some other requestor) groups by departure date, there will only be 1 group per date
* We aren't doing this in CNG, and so we can have  different timestamps for the same departure date
* This means that we are returning multiple groups back per departure date in this scenario, +which could upset the requestor+

I did a bit of looking through the SOLr extracts and responses at date fields and found that:

* For FH - 12:00 was being defaulted as the time for departure, arrival, checkin and checkout dates
* For FC - 12:00 was being defaulted as the departure and arrival dates (no defaulting of time for pickup & dropoff dates, these are exact)
* For HO - 12:00 was being defaulted for check in and check out dates
* For CO - no defaulting for pickup & dropoff dates

This does make sense, because these fields are really intended as 'date only'.

From what I can see in CNG, all the FH and HO check in and check out times contain 12:00. So it looks like we have similar logic already in place to default those times. Or is this a quirk of the reference data being used in the lookup?

I think that we should do something about the affected dates, otherwise we will have problems grouping by these date fields in SOLr b/w and the full API.

What would be the impacts if we did this....?

* Change required to the batch controller logic
* We have more than 1 version of the departure and arrival date fields in the FH proposition (date, secs & string versions) so that would need to be considered
* Would it have any effect on the full API design....I don't think so, but it might change our advice on how to search using these date fields

As per the working group call, assigning to Pooja for investigation.

Jon

column1857:
27/Sep/23 2:08 PM;62e3f1525f7842fb1294980c;Hi [~accountid:5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358] ,
Team analyzed on this JIRA. Below are our observations on check-in, checkout, departure and arrival fields.

* Departure and arrival fields for both FC and FH don’t have default time with T12:00:00 instead we have different time stamps as per OJResponse.
* As for check-in and checkout date fields we are hardcoding T12:00:00 in HO and FH and there is no reference data being used in the lookup.

If we hardcode the value of departure and arrival date’s time stamp to T12:00:00 then we might have deviation in departure and arrival time with respect to OJ response time stamp. In case if the time stamp is set to default, then *depDateString* and *depDateSecs* will change accordingly.



We need confirmation on below points. 

# Suppose depDate is set as Aug 01,2023 @ 12:00:00. So here the *depDateString* and  *depDateSecs* time stamp can be 11:00:00. *Is this date format fine?*
# This change will be affected to for all inbound and outbound date fields (*flightDepDate_n_O and flightArrDate_n_I*) as well. Then we may need to change 12 fields in each FC and FH propositions in addition to above mentioned fields. Could you please confirm on this?

Thanks & Regards, 

Merin Joseph
column1858:
27/Sep/23 4:16 PM;5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358;Hi [~accountid:62e3f1525f7842fb1294980c] ,

We don’t need or want to make any changes to the flight matrix fields, they should remain as per current logic (exact date and time are taken from the availability response) 

Just talking about FH for the moment

* fields  in-scope are arrDate, arrDateSecs, arrDateString, depDate, depDateSecs, depDateString, checkInDate, checkOutDate
* checkInDate, checkOutDate already have the required logic
* for the others, please use the date from the OJ response and set the time to always be 12:00:00
* In terms of the datetime format we are storing dates +in the index+, aren’t we currently storing them all as  2024-01-17T21:55:00.000 ie without Z but with millisecs? We should keep the format of these fields consistent with all the others - it’s just the time value that we want to adjust here.  
* The secs fields won’t actually display the time value but will be calculated using it

Does this make sense? I realise that this means that the arr* and dep* fields will diverge from what’s in the OJ response but this is reqd for useful grouping on these fields and to match what happens today.

Once we’ve agreed this I’m happy to list out the changes reqd for the other props.

Thanks,

Jon
column1859: 28/Sep/23 7:47 AM;62e3f1525f7842fb1294980c;Update: Assigning to Pooja for further analysis
column1860:
28/Sep/23 12:12 PM;6392214d3c26ca7fa0d75c1d;Hi [~accountid:5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358] ,

Please let me know if I'm interpreting this correctly. 

In FH, we have to make changes in the timestamp for below fields:

* arrDate
* arrDateSecs
* arrDateString
* depDate
* depDateSecs
* depDateString

by replacing the time with T12:00:00.000 as we need to use this for grouping the fields.

Let us know if we have to make the changes in other fields in other propositions as well.

Thanks,

Pooja
column1861:
28/Sep/23 5:17 PM;5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358;Hi Pooja,

Yes you have understood this correctly, we take the date portion from OJ and set the time to 12 o clock - in the existing time format standard of T12:00:00.000.

Looking at all propositions:

* FH - arrDate, arrDateSecs, arrDateString, depDate, depDateSecs, depDateString, checkInDate (*y), checkOutDate (*y)   should all have time portion set to 12 o clock
* FC - arrivalDate, depDate
* HO - checkInDate (*y), checkOutDate (*y)
* CO - no fields require changing

From Merin’s analysis the (*y) fields should already have this logic in place.

Note for testing - default pick up and drop off times are used for CO availability queries and looking in Kibana the time chosen looks to be 12 o’clock. So I think we will have all these times set to 12:00 for CO, but this will be coming from the actual availability response rather than any hardcoding logic. I’ve checked back in APC and all the CO availability in the DB has the same timestamps. 

Thanks,

Jon

column1: IAG/BAH Review Comments to be made time bound
column45:
As a standard across all the projects - Review comments generally span to 2-5 days from the time design is shared/design walk-through is completed. In CNG/AHP, design comments from the stakeholders have spanned more than 3 weeks of time 

Eg: Common API, SOLR API, SIP API

+Assumption:+

When the cost estimates were shared only one week was factored into planning -

2 days for review comments to be shared and frozen and 3 days to incorporate review comments

+Impact:+

Resources are stretched on addressing the comments on adhoc basis and deferring their planned deliveries

Planned activities to be re-prioritized resulting in overall impact to timelines and cost

+Mitigation:+

# Review process board to be set up
# Cadence with the stakeholders on the review comments to be shared within 3 days of the design walk-through
# Ensure stakeholders availability and commitment during these stages
# Build to commence only after LLD is signed off

column1: Setup of live Kibana features, so that it is ready for Commercial use
column45:
The idea of this Jira is to consider what setup might be required in Kibana before we open it up to the business and to deliver it. The kind of things I’m thinking of are things like the Data Views we have in the on-prem UAT Kibana Environment, that make it easier to do Kibana searches.

We might get some info on this when we look at the AWS Kibana we will use for e2e UAT.

The way that user access is setup and organised may or may not affect this. eg does it need to be setup per user role.

If we are delivering any Kibana related Dashboards etc (from other Jiras) this might need consideration.

We also need to decide if this is simple and BAH can do the work, or if it neds a TCS delivery.

Jon

column1: AWS Development Environment
column45:
Raising this Jira in the hindsight - 

Assumption : TCS was to have a working(connectivity established) infrastructure before the build commenced

It was advised to commence the build with out infrastructure in place.  Environment has been delivered in piecemeal. To progress with the build, project team had to work with limitations such - 

no SONARQube - instead add in Sonarlint plugin for static code coverage and sonar and jcoco plugin,  reading from respective service constants rather than parameter store etc

Impact : 

Overall code refactor will be required when we have full infrastructure in place. 

TCS plan will be impacted as the amount of refactor cannot be quantified right now as we only have one working environment currently for both development and system testing.

When we move to higher environments -again because of the way it is connected (multiple instance) - code refactor needs to be considered              

Actions:

# Assign resources - review the code built so far and raise the risks with which team has developed - Sana
# Walk-through and documentation of the environments delivered to project team -  Shaf
# Assign timescales to these as project team is already into system testing for SOLR and SIP APIs, and build completed for Full API

column1858: 03/Aug/23 11:28 AM;635145e8f7ad721e784c7e20;Hi Sana, yes please it would be good to have a call regarding this so I’ll put in a call.  Planning activities should be captured and included as part of the project plan by the project manager, I would not be expecting the developers and test team to add ad hoc activities independently.  If this does happen, then there will be a lack of control over the plan and the impact to the plan.  I would be expecting them to assign tickets where required and raise bugs against activities in the call.

column1: Commercial Analysis - POC
column45:
h4. Approach 1: Direct Batch Insert or Bulk Insert CSV from Spring Boot Application

This approach involves the Spring Boot application reading data in batches from an OpenSearch index, converting the data into Java objects, and then inserting these objects into the target SQL database in batches. Optionally, data can be temporarily stored in CSV format and inserted using a Bulk Insert command for potentially improved performance.(Need to explore Spring Batch here ).

*Pros*:

* *Flexibility and Control:* Java applications can dynamically build and execute SQL queries, allowing for complex logic before data insertion. This includes the ability to adjust batch sizes based on performance metrics.
* *Error Handling*: Provides the ability to implement sophisticated error handling and retry mechanisms at the batch level. This can be especially useful for ensuring data integrity and managing partial failures.
* *Transaction Management:* Offers fine-grained control over transactions, including the capability to commit or roll back transactions based on specific criteria or outcomes of batch operations.

*Cons*:

* *Performance Overhead*: For each batch insert we need to maintain a database connection, which can introduce latency and lower throughput compared to bulk insert methods, especially when dealing with millions of records.
* *Resource Intensive:* Managing a high volume of database connections and transactions can be resource-intensive for both the application and the database server, potentially leading to performance bottlenecks.(In our case the connections should not be huge as its already being scheduled ,there is no such adhoc queries where data being stored in db )
* *File Management:* Requires additional steps to manage CSV files, including writing to disk, ensuring file security, and cleaning up after uploads. This can introduce complexity, especially when dealing with data split across multiple files.(In case of BULK INSERT CSV from java)

h4. Considerations

* Evaluate the optimal batch size for performance.
* Ensure the Spring Boot application has the necessary permissions for Bulk Insert operations (ex BULK INSERT CSV ).
* Implement robust error handling and logging for batch insert operations

h4. Approach 2: Combination of Spring Boot Application and SQL Server Scripts for Bulk Insert

h4. *Description*

In this approach, the Spring Boot application processes data and stores it in a CSV file on the server. Once the data writing is complete, a SQL Server script is triggered to perform a Bulk Insert from the CSV into the database.

h4. *Pros*:

* *High Performance:* Bulk upload operations are optimized for high-speed data insertion, significantly reducing the time required to import large volumes of data compared to batch inserts.
* *Reduced Network Overhead:* By storing data in CSV files and performing bulk uploads directly on the server, network traffic between the application and database server is minimized, which is beneficial for large datasets.

h4. *Cons*:

* *SQL Server Scripting*: Dependency on scripting and permissions within SQL Server.
* *Error Handling and Data Integrity:* While SQL Server can log errors during bulk uploads, handling these errors and ensuring data integrity (especially with all-or-nothing requirements) can be more challenging compared to batch inserts.
* *File Management:* Requires additional steps to manage CSV files, including writing to disk, ensuring file security, and cleaning up after uploads. This can introduce complexity, especially when dealing with data split across multiple files.
* *Preparation Time:* The time it takes to generate and write data to a CSV file must be considered.
* *File Accessibility:* The CSV files need to be accessible to the SQL Server. This can introduce challenges in distributed environments or cloud deployments where the Java application and SQL Server are not co-located.
* *Limited Control from Java:* Once the bulk insert operation is initiated, the Java application has limited control over the process.

h4. *Considerations*:

* Implement a mechanism to signal the completion of data writing to CSV.
* Determine how to split or manage large CSV files for insertion.(if data size is large)
* Develop logging and error handling mechanisms within SQL Server scripts.
* Develop a mechanism to trigger the mail in case of BULK CSV INSERT failed.(As its running in SQL server)

h4. Approach 3: Calling a stored procedure from a Java application to perform a bulk insert operation from a CSV file.

h4. *Description:*

When we call a stored procedure from a Java application to perform a bulk insert operation from a CSV file, the process involves establishing a connection to the SQL Server database from your Java application. Here's how the process works and its implications on connections and resource usage:

h4. *Process Overview:*

* *Java Application Initiates Connection*: Java application uses JDBC (Java Database Connectivity) to establish a connection to the SQL Server database. This connection is necessary for any operation that involves communicating with the database, including executing stored procedures.
* *Calling the Stored Procedure*: Once the connection is established, Java application executes a SQL command to call the stored procedure that have defined in SQL Server for performing the bulk insert operation.
* *Stored Procedure Execution:* The stored procedure runs entirely on the SQL Server, utilizing the SQL Server's resources. The bulk insert operation, as defined within the stored procedure, reads data from the CSV file and inserts it into the target table in SQL Server.
* *Connection Remains Active:* Throughout the execution of the stored procedure, the JDBC connection from Java application to the SQL Server remains open and active. Once the stored procedure completes its execution, we can close the connection from Java application.

h4. *Pros*:

* *Performance Efficiency:* Bulk insert operations are highly optimized for performance in SQL Server, allowing for the rapid insertion of large volumes of data with minimal impact on database resources compared to row-by-row insertion or batch operations.
* *Reduced Network Traffic*: Since the bulk insert operation is handled entirely within SQL Server, this approach minimizes the network traffic between the Java application and the database, which is especially beneficial for large datasets or in environments with limited network bandwidth

h4. *Cons*:

* *Complex Error Handling*: Handling errors that occur during the bulk insert operation can be more complex, as detailed information about the failure needs to be communicated back to the Java application for appropriate action or logging.
* *Dependency on Database Permissions*: Executing stored procedures that perform bulk insert operations requires appropriate permissions on the SQL Server. Managing these permissions and ensuring security can add administrative overhead.
* *File Accessibility:* The CSV files need to be accessible to the SQL Server. This can introduce challenges in distributed environments or cloud deployments where the Java application and SQL Server are not co-located.

column1864:
06/Mar/24 9:37 AM;712020:8d138859-363b-4f27-8fcb-f73aeda9b37f;Few questions regarding option 1:

# Do we have to insert data from existing sql server as a one off before going to production or no data is needed to insert at the time of cut over to live?
# Approximate number of records to be inserted each time the process runs?  Is it in millions of records every time or a few thousand?  This is important to understand the performance of this option.
# Converting to CSV and bulk insert from java objects may not be the best way as it involves additional file handling operations.

[~accountid:5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358] [~accountid:712020:b846cd8c-69cd-498e-9221-cf5454894f31] [~accountid:64259c719796ea0a8719cd03] [~accountid:635145e8f7ad721e784c7e20]
column1865:
06/Mar/24 9:44 AM;712020:b846cd8c-69cd-498e-9221-cf5454894f31;[~accountid:712020:8d138859-363b-4f27-8fcb-f73aeda9b37f] 
About question 3:
To dismiss completely the CSV/bulk insert option we need to be sure of the good enough performance of “single row insert" via the Java SpringBatch app.
On the other side we are not sure that a bulk insert into SQL Server can be done from remote and not from the SQL Server VM itself. This is an investigation that must be done.
Last but not least, there is already a system with a stored procedure which is in production for the  extemporary of bulk insert of CSV data files in case of different sources of data.

So we have to keep this option still open…
column1866: 06/Mar/24 9:56 AM;712020:8d138859-363b-4f27-8fcb-f73aeda9b37f;[~accountid:712020:b846cd8c-69cd-498e-9221-cf5454894f31] Not dismissing it at all and may be that is what we need to use as it resembles the current process.  My main question is to understand from the business, the number of records to insert every time and do we have to perform any deletes every time when there is an exception.  If the records to be inserted in thousands, then java batch insert will be fine ( usually an optimized batch takes around 4 seconds for 10k records depending on other factors), if it is in millions, then db loader may be the option.  We can discuss in today’s meeting but before that if [~accountid:5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358] can provide some insights into the numbers, it will be useful
column1867:
06/Mar/24 10:04 AM;5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358;Hi [~accountid:712020:8d138859-363b-4f27-8fcb-f73aeda9b37f] - the number of rows question is hard to answer, because 1) the queries haven’t been written yet 2) performance is likely to influence how the queries are split up and 3) every query will be different. The solution definitely needs to be able to cope with millions of records. although hundreds of thousands might be more common. 

The solution needs to be based around high volume rather than 1000s of records.

Jon
column1868: 06/Mar/24 10:13 AM;712020:8d138859-363b-4f27-8fcb-f73aeda9b37f;Hi [~accountid:5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358] -  Is the query expected to fetch millions of rows from Opensearch or is it in few thousands?  I am going through the HLD (WIP) any my question specifically is,  hundreds of queries returning small volumes of data or few queries returning large volumes of data?  This will play an important role in choosing the best solution.  Is it possible to get some information from the existing solution on these numbers?
column1869:
06/Mar/24 12:55 PM;616007b564ff01007180a9c5;see [https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/import-export/bulk-import-and-export-of-data-sql-server?view=sql-server-ver16|https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/import-export/bulk-import-and-export-of-data-sql-server?view=sql-server-ver16|smart-link]  

As I understood those docs, BULK IMPORT imports from a file accessible from the database server, whereas bcp imports from a file accessible from the bcp utility to a remote database.
column1870:
08/Mar/24 5:23 PM;63f748f7e76fc61320f5de04;Few Observations on OpenSearch:-

# We have tried executing given query in Query Workbench it worked with
 few acceptable function changes in the sql query (*Screenshot-1*).
!Screenshot-1.PNG|width=1015,height=519!

This is the offical document of supported functions in open search but we are not sure whether these are supported in DevTools or Query Workbench of open search [https://opensearch.org/docs/latest/search-plugins/sql/functions/|https://opensearch.org/docs/latest/search-plugins/sql/functions/|smart-link]  .However the same was not working in Dev Tools of open search or local tools like postman. (*Screenshot-2*). 
!Screenshot-2.PNG|width=1009,height=511!
We will try to find out the function if any which is not supported in Dev Tools in open search.
# When we try to send via json query prefixed as SELECT * or SELECT all columns we don't get any data on paginating via cursors (*Screenshot-3*) 
!Screenshot-3.PNG|width=731,height=452!
though we are able to get data with fewer columns from postman and from java code in the subsequent calls via cursor. As far as we remember it used to work in Elastic search , might be issue in configuration or may be it is not supported in open search. We will investigate on it further.
# We have a test index co_cng with highest number of records ,i.e. 94683 and on the first postman request we get records and cursor (*Screenshot-4*). 
!Screenshot-4.PNG|width=733,height=462!
But when we try to further send that cursor it fails. 
# Also the cursor part is not working in devtools of OpenSearch dashboard (*Screenshot-5*)
!Screenshot-5.PNG|width=1022,height=510!
# Have attached a document with few more pointers regarding open search and we are still working on it (Doc:-OpenSearch_POC_CA)[^0f67294f-f6d4-4c5b-a040-43f3c172f0aa]
column1871: 11/Mar/24 1:38 AM;64259c719796ea0a8719cd03;[https://iagtech.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/CNG/pages/1257275394/CA+-+Commercial+Analysis+HLD+-+Updated+WIP|https://iagtech.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/CNG/pages/1257275394/CA+-+Commercial+Analysis+HLD+-+Updated+WIP|smart-link]  for reference
column1872:
11/Mar/24 7:58 AM;63f748f7e76fc61320f5de04;Upon analyzing the ad hoc query requirements, achieving pagination in the query workbench is possible using the 'limit' and 'offset' parameters. However, this approach is not feasible for us due to the large volume of data we handle. In this context, 'limit' represents the maximum number of records displayed at once, while 'offset' indicates the starting point of the records. (Screenshot-6)

!Screenshot-6.PNG|width=721,height=464!

Unfortunately, there is a limitation of 10,000 records, preventing the system from reading beyond this threshold. For instance, 'Select * from fh_cng LIMIT 5000 offset 5001' will result in an error (Screenshot-7), as it cannot exceed the limit of 10,000 records.

!Screenshot-7.PNG|width=471,height=299!

We will explore the possibility of altering the limit configuration with the configuration team, but as of now, this limitation remains in place.
column1873:
11/Mar/24 10:00 AM;5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358;Scott and I did some reviewing of current data set size for CA queries and expected increases for CNG. For the 5 existing scheduled reports the estimates result set sizes are

* 3* 1.5 million
* 1* 250k
* 1* 112k

We’ve then allowed for a further 16 regular reports each returning 10s to 100s of thousands of records. These figures are just to assist the POC because the queries aren’t known at this stage or how they will be split up. The major assumption from a POC point of view, is that these vols assume the whole data set is returned by a single query rather than split into separate queries.



[https://baplc.sharepoint.com/:x:/r/sites/BAHProjects/_layouts/15/Doc.aspx?sourcedoc=%7BB5A669FF-FEAA-4FE0-AD65-9B41735DDA63%7D&file=Guestimates%20for%20CA%20query%20result%20set%20size.xlsx&action=default&mobileredirect=true|https://baplc.sharepoint.com/:x:/r/sites/BAHProjects/_layouts/15/Doc.aspx?sourcedoc=%7BB5A669FF-FEAA-4FE0-AD65-9B41735DDA63%7D&file=Guestimates%20for%20CA%20query%20result%20set%20size.xlsx&action=default&mobileredirect=true|smart-link]

column1874:
14/Mar/24 9:29 AM;5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358;Hi [~accountid:64259c719796ea0a8719cd03] - I’ve attached 4 queries one for each proposition to assist with the POC. These won’t be the final queries but they are indicative of the level of complexity and operations in the current live CA scripts.

Jon
column1875:
14/Mar/24 2:20 PM;5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358;Hi [~accountid:64259c719796ea0a8719cd03] - regarding screenshot 2 and the idea that different operations may be supported between Workbench and Dev tools:

* I’ve used all the functions /operations that are in your query successfully in dev tools
* Your query looks a bit odd due to specifying (different) numbers or records with both the Limit and fetch_size 
* Playing with my CA queries…I can control return set size using both of these params in isolation but the query fails when both are present. So I think this may the problem for this example. Fingers crossed this means that there isn’t any real difference between the operations supported between the 2 tools
* I’ve also found that dev tools can struggle with white space / line breaks etc and sometimes this can stop valid queries from running

Thanks,

Jon
column1876:
14/Mar/24 2:46 PM;63f748f7e76fc61320f5de04;Hi [~accountid:5ff613f64d2179006ebdc358] ,

Thanks for your keen observation, even we figured it out today that we were using limit and fetch_size and that was the issue. So we can assume for now that both dev tools and query workbench give similar results

Query given for elastic search was changed to make it supported for open search.
changes made:-
•	Replaced RTRIM(TO_CHAR(arrDate, 'DAY' )), to_char(arrDate, '-DD-MON-YY') with
DATE_FORMAT(arrDate, 'EEEE'), '-', DATE_FORMAT(arrDate, 'dd-MMM-yy')
As RTRIM and TO_CHAR not supported in open Search instead used date_format
•	Replaced COALESCE with IFNULL
•	Replaced current_date with NOW()

Below is the final query is which we tested from our java code to convert response into csv and we also tested it from local tools like postman(added 1=1 in where clause to get all index data ):-
{
"query":"SELECT destAirportCode, hotelID, CONCAT(DATE_FORMAT(arrDate, 'EEEE'),'-',DATE_FORMAT(arrDate,'dd-MMM-yy')) AS OUT_ARR_DATE, requestedCabinCodes, duration, displayTotalPrice, boardBasis, CASE WHEN boardBasis = 'Room only' THEN 'AO' WHEN boardBasis = 'Continental breakfast' THEN 'CB' WHEN boardBasis = 'Full breakfast' THEN 'BB' WHEN boardBasis = 'Half board' THEN 'HB' WHEN boardBasis = 'Full board' THEN 'FB' WHEN boardBasis = 'All inclusive' THEN 'AI' WHEN boardBasis = 'Bed & breakfast' THEN 'BB' WHEN boardBasis = 'Self catering' THEN 'SC' ELSE 'Unknown' END AS JF_board_basis, roomType, depAirportCode_1_O, arrAirportCode_1_O, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_3_O, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_2_O, arrAirportCode_1_O)) AS OUT_ARR_AIR, IFNULL(depAirportCode_2_I, IFNULL(depAirportCode_3_I, IFNULL(depAirportCode_4_I, IFNULL(depAirportCode_5_I,depAirportCode_6_I)))) AS RET_DEP_AIR, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_2_I, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_3_I, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_4_I, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_5_I,arrAirportCode_6_I)))) AS RET_VIA, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_6_I, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_5_I, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_4_I, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_3_I,arrAirportCode_2_I)))) AS RET_ARR_AIR, flightCarrier_1_O, flightNumber_1_O, IFNULL(flightCarrier_2_I, IFNULL(flightCarrier_3_I, IFNULL(flightCarrier_4_I, IFNULL(flightCarrier_5_I,flightCarrier_6_I)))) AS RET_CARRIER, IFNULL(flightNumber_2_I, IFNULL(flightNumber_3_I, IFNULL(flightNumber_4_I, IFNULL(flightNumber_5_I,flightNumber_6_I)))) AS RET_FLIGHT_NO, currencyCode, market, hotelRatePlanCode, hotelSupplierSource, roomLandCost, hotelPromotionCode, flightCost, fareClass, fareClass_1_O, IFNULL(fareClass_2_I, IFNULL(fareClass_3_I, IFNULL(fareClass_4_I, IFNULL(fareClass_5_I,fareClass_6_I)))) AS RET_FARE_CLASS FROM fh_cng WHERE displayTotalPrice IS NOT NULL AND duration = 15 AND market = 'GB' AND destAirportCode = 'SYD' AND requestedCabinCodes = 'M' AND DATE_FORMAT(checkInDate, 'E') LIKE 'TUESDAY%' AND arrDate > NOW() and arrDate < DATE_ADD(NOW(), INTERVAL 340 DAY) OR 1=1;",
"fetch_size":10000
}

!Screenshot-8.PNG|width=719,height=427!



We get first set of data with fetch_size but for next we get error (Screenshot-8). So to support pagination we tried reducing query size and it worked, we are getting all cursors and full datarows (csv attached:- query_output). Here is the reduced query :-

{
"query":"SELECT destAirportCode, hotelID, CONCAT(DATE_FORMAT(arrDate, 'EEEE'),'-',DATE_FORMAT(arrDate,'dd-MMM-yy')) AS OUT_ARR_DATE, requestedCabinCodes, duration, displayTotalPrice, boardBasis, roomType, depAirportCode_1_O, arrAirportCode_1_O, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_3_O, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_2_O, arrAirportCode_1_O)) AS OUT_ARR_AIR, IFNULL(depAirportCode_2_I, IFNULL(depAirportCode_3_I, IFNULL(depAirportCode_4_I, IFNULL(depAirportCode_5_I,depAirportCode_6_I)))) AS RET_DEP_AIR, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_2_I, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_3_I, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_4_I, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_5_I,arrAirportCode_6_I)))) AS RET_VIA, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_6_I, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_5_I, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_4_I, IFNULL(arrAirportCode_3_I,arrAirportCode_2_I)))) AS RET_ARR_AIR, flightCarrier_1_O, flightNumber_1_O, currencyCode, market, hotelRatePlanCode, hotelSupplierSource, roomLandCost, hotelPromotionCode, flightCost, fareClass, fareClass_1_O FROM fh_cng WHERE displayTotalPrice IS NOT NULL AND duration = 15 AND market = 'GB' AND destAirportCode = 'SYD' AND requestedCabinCodes = 'M' AND DATE_FORMAT(checkInDate, 'E') LIKE 'TUESDAY%' AND arrDate > NOW() and arrDate < DATE_ADD(NOW(), INTERVAL 340 DAY) OR 1=1;",
"fetch_size":5000
}
Time Taken = 3.8 min

[^query_output.csv]

column1905: Full API (Internal, External) - BA Holidays Pricing Cache API

column1: Implement NOT logic for full API
column45:
*Background*

As part of developing b/w SOLr API, it was recognised we needed to implement NOT logic via ! and - characters.

With this functionality present in the common API, it would also be possible to develop the full API to use NOT logic and it would be useful to the business

*Requirement*

*I want* requests sent to the Full API to be able to use a NOT operator *so that* the API has the ability to exclude specific data from certain responses 

*Acceptance Criteria*

*Given* the API is available and supports querying
*When* the consumer sends a request to filter data using the NOT operator
*Then* the API should process the request successfully
*And* return the filtered data excluding the specified condition
*And* the NOT operator can be used in combination with all other operators

*Design Consideration*

Not essential to be implemented in exactly the same way as it was for for b/w API, although this might be simplest.

column1856:
27/Jul/23 5:05 PM;6422c457407493675d482097;Hi All,

Please tag all the open Akamai IP's Jira tickets here so collective details can be shared with CTT Team.
column1857:
25/Aug/23 9:58 AM;6422c457407493675d482097;Hi All,

Please find the updates after the discussion with CTT team.

*Current approach* will be that ip's given by Akamai will be whitlisted within AWS to allow the requests to flow within CNG and there will be a activity to be added in support and operations after production that every quarter new ip's will be shared by Akamai and support team needs to whitelist in AWS to run the app smoothly.

*Next iteration -* these ip's will be removed from AWS configurations and Akamai will share the encrypted header that will be validated within AWS to flow the requests within CNG and there will be no support/operations overhead of changing the ip's every quarter.



fyi, [~accountid:5ad8cbca926ac92a7c0e11bb] , [~accountid:635145e8f7ad721e784c7e20]  , [~accountid:616007b564ff01007180a9c5]

column1859: 21/Feb/24 1:16 PM;5d14ba9bbda1410bc8e04883;Had a chat with CTTI team.The Akamai IP’s change twice a year and application teams are given enough time to prepare for the [change. |http://change.No]Akamai header encryption is enabled only for on prem and not for cloud origins.

column1: SSL Certificates in AWS
column45:
The advice back in 2020 was that we could use wildcard certs in AWS.

BA Cyber Security have refused DC exit to use wildcard certs and instead they had to list all the domains in the SAN (subject alternative names); up to 500.

The CNG project should probably do the same.  So still only one certificate would be required but the project would have to work out in advance all the subdomains that will be need and list them in the SAN (Subject Alternative Names).

Version 1 have to date used Wild Card certs.  We need Version 1 to issue certs from AWS Certificate Manager.  AWS Certificate Manager auto renews certificates.
